description: From Middle English streke, from Old English strica, from Proto-Germanic *strikiz, from Proto-Indo-European *streyg- (‚Äúline‚Äù). Related to North Frisian strijck, Old Saxon striki, Middle Low German streke, Low German streek, Danish streg, Swedish streck, Norwegian Bokm√•l strek, Icelandic stryk, strykr, Dutch streek, Afrikaans streek, Old High German strih, German Strich, Gothic êçÉêçÑêçÇêåπêå∫êçÉ (striks).

entries.meaning: An irregular line left from smearing or motion.
examples: The picture I took out the car window had streaks.

entries.meaning: A continuous series of like events.
examples: I hope I can keep up this streak of accomplishments.
I was on a winning streak until the fourth game, when I was dealt terrible cards.

entries.meaning: The color of the powder of a mineral. So called, because a simple field test for a mineral is to streak it against unglazed white porcelain.
A moth of the family Geometridae, Chesias legatella.
A tendency or characteristic, but not a dominant or pervasive one.
examples: She's a quiet, bookish person, but she has a rebellious streak.

entries.meaning: A rung or round of a ladder.
The act of streaking, or running naked through a public area.

verbs.description: streak (third-person singular simple present streaks, present participle streaking, simple past and past participle streaked)

examples: If you clean a window in direct sunlight, it will streak.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To run naked in public. (Contrast flash)
examples: It was a pleasant game until some guy went streaking across the field.
You will streak a window by cleaning it in direct sunlight.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, UK, Scotland) To stretch; to extend; hence, to lay out, as a dead body.
